issue.title: bugfix - convertIO broken references to np.ndarray

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body: Some references in the converter module (from #980) where mistakenly to the function `np.array` instead of the array type `np.ndarray`. This is now fixed.

body:
Here's another one, from
https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/pull/1201/checks?check_run_id=3176902542

See details for error message:

issue.title: removing tests for data downloader dependent on third party website, change in test dataset for test_time_series_neighbors

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
Two testing improvements:

1. Remove test for data downloads that is dependent on a third party website #1257 

2. Change test dataset in test_time_series_neighbors to use UnitTest instead of ItalyPowerDemand.  #1235

issue.title: Prophet custom seasonalities

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
> #### Reference Issues/PRs

See the feature enhancement request [#1374](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/issues/1374)


> #### What does this implement/fix? Explain your changes.

This allows you to add multiple custom seasonalities to the wrapped version of prophet. The prophet parameter `add_seasonality` can now be either a dictionary (for backward compatibility) or a list that contains multiple dictionaries, each one of them adds a different custom seasonality.

> #### Does your contribution introduce a new dependency? If yes, which one?

Nope.

> #### What should a reviewer concentrate their feedback on?

There's not much code changes.

> #### Any other comments?

I really appreciate this library/project and this is my first PR ever ^^ .

> #### PR checklist

##### For all contributions
- [x] I've added myself to the [list of contributors](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/main/.all-contributorsrc).
- [ ] Optionally, I've updated sktime's [CODEOWNERS](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/main/CODEOWNERS) to receive notifications about future changes to these files.
- [ ] I've added unit tests and made sure they pass locally.

##### For new estimators
- [ ] I've added the estimator to the online documentation.
- [ ] I've updated the existing example notebooks or provided a new one to showcase how my estimator works.

issue.title: First step of prediction interval refactor for forecasters

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
#### Reference Issues/PRs
Start working on #984

Started with the refactor of the base class. Following STEP 12 and discussion in #984

#### What does this implement/fix? Explain your changes.
* add todo's for what needs to be deprecated/where deprecation warnings will be needed
* have everything that is supposed to be deprecated in `predict()` in an additional else statement
* add abstract method with signature `predict_interval(self, fh=None, X=None, alpha=Union[float, np.ndarray[float, dim=1]]) -> pd.DataFrame` 
* make `predict()` call `predict_interval()` unless the boolean flag of `old_predict_interval_logic` is set to true
* move methods related to prediction intervals that are specific to one particular forecaster to that forecaster, for now -> We can further refactor them there
	* more specifically: move `_get_pred_int` to `_tbats`; move `compute_pred_int` to `theta`, completly delete `_get_pred_int` and directly call `_compute_pred_err()` instead. 

#### Does your contribution introduce a new dependency? If yes, which one?
No.

#### What should the reviewers concentrate their feedback on
* I think I followed precisely what is suggested in STEP 12, except for this one: 
       * STEP 12 suggests moving `_get_pred_int` to theta, but I think it should be safe to completely delete it.
       
#### Any other comments?
- `predict()` now contains code duplicates but I thought it would be good for readability to have everything that is going to be deprecated in one else statement such that it can easily be deleted.
- As the next step I think we need to follow through with these changes in the inheriting classes before we can add the deprecation warning. But before implementing `_predict_interval()` in the inheriting classes, we should probably decide how the user can decide on the strategy for computing prediction intervals (either `PredIntervalAdder` or just as arguments in the constructor, see discussion about this in #984). 

pinging @fkiraly and @mloning

body: One possible solution would be to replace `time.time()` with `time.perf_counter()`. Alternatively, we could remove the assert statement in the test.

Yep- time.perf_counter() is preferred to time.time().

Based on documentation in time library it seems like it should fix the problem.

issue.title: Replace time.time with time.perf_counter

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
#### Reference Issues/PRs
Fixes https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/issues/1194

#### What does this implement/fix? Explain your changes.
* replaces `time.time` with `time.perf_counter`

body: More details on why `perf_counter` should fix this issue: https://stackoverflow.com/a/25787875/9334962

Perhaps I'm really slow to understand, but how does the content of the stackoverflow post relate to the bug? What exactly in `time.time` caused the bug, why does the move to `perf_counter` fix it?

Sorry for asking, but when reviewing a bugfix, I should understand what has happened in fixing it. I'm probably just slow/dense.

My understanding is that `time.time` may be too imprecise to measure very short run times, hence sometimes it reports zero seconds elapsed. We check if run times are always strictly positive, so this then raises the error. `time.perf_counter` should fix that because it's more precise. Why it's more precise is described in the above StackOverflow post.
